PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is required to: 
 
(i)  Undertake sector preparatory work, define the scope of the ensuing investment program, 
and undertake (a) technical feasibility assessment, (b) safeguards due diligence, and (c) 
financial and economic viability assessment of the ensuing investment program; 
(ii) Assist the Delhi Jal Board (DJB) in undertaking advance contracting actions for project 1 
of the proposed investment program to: (a) appoint the project management consultant 
(PMC), and (b) prepare and manage the bid to procure the design-build-finance-operate-
transfer (DBFOT) contractor for the Wazirabad water treatment plant (WTP); and 
(iii) Assist the DJB in establishing service level benchmarks (SLBs) for the water network 
improvement DBFOT contract under project 2 of the proposed investment program. This 
will cover one pilot district metered area (DMA) and include undertaking: 
a.  Surveys  and  investigations  of  the  water  network  to  identify  the  alignment, 
condition,  physical  characteristics  of  the  network,  and  quality  of  connections 
between the distribution main and house service;  
b.  Household  surveys  and  data  collection  on  connections,  working  condition  of 
meters, quality of water supplied, and reliability (pressure and continuity) of water 
supplied; and 
c.  Non-revenue water (NRW) baseline surveys through comparison of inflows into 
the  DMA  and  monitoring  using  electronic  bulk  flow  meters  and  meters  at 
consumer points.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,400,000 equivalent, of which $800,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other 
sources) and $500,000 from the Multi-Donor Trust Fund1 under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility (WFPF) and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in 
the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, communication facilities for 
consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table 
A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  Nine  individuals  comprising  3  international  consultants  and  6  national  consultants 
(providing  39  person-months  of  input)  will  be  engaged  to  undertake  the  TA.  Table  A4.3 
summarizes the consulting services requirement for the individuals. A national firm will be 
engaged  to  undertake  surveys  and  investigations  and  establish  the  SLBs,  and  will  be 
supervised by the Asset Management Specialist. The firm will be appointed using a Consultants’ 
Qualifications  Selection  (CQS)  given  the  highly  specialized  nature  of  the  surveys  and 
investigations. Socioeconomic and willingness to pay surveys will be undertaken by the project 
management consultancy appointed through advance actions.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the TA consultants are described in paragraphs 6 to 
14. 
 
  1.  Outline terms of reference for international consultants 
 
6.  Project Management Expert and Team Leader. The Team Leader will be an Engineer 
with minimum 20 years of experience in the infrastructure industry with a focus on urban 
services.  She/he  will  (i)  assist  on  advance  contracting  actions  to  appoint  the  PMC;  (ii) 
coordinate  technical  feasibility  assessment,  safeguards  assessment,  and  economic  and 
financial viability assessment; and (iii) assist on bidding document preparation and bid process 
management for the DBFOT contract for the WTP. All team members will report to the Team 
Leader. 
 
7.  Water Supply Engineer. The Water Supply Engineer will be an Engineer with minimum 
20 years of experience in the water supply and sewerage sector. She/he will (i) draft the terms 
of reference for the PMC; (ii) undertake technical assessment and define the scope of the 
investment program; (iii) undertake quality check of the engineering designs undertaken by the 
PMC prior to bidding of the DBFOT contract for the WTP; and (iv) review the specifications and 
functional guarantees in the DBFOT contract for the WTP. 
 
8.  Asset  Management  and  Nonrevenue  Water  (NRW)  Specialist.  The  Asset 
Management Specialist will be an Engineer with minimum 10 years of experience in a water 
utility. She/he will (i) appoint a suitable firm to undertake surveys and investigations; (ii) plan and 
oversee the surveys and investigations to establish the SLBs; and (iii) define the performance 
parameters in the DBFOT contract for the WTP and the network. 
 
  2.  Outline terms of reference for national consultants 
 
9.  Financial Management Specialist. The Financial Specialist will have a background in 
accounting  and/or  financial  management  and/or  Masters  in  Business  Administration  with 
extensive knowledge of working with service utilities – power, telecom or water for a minimum 
10 years. She/he will (i) undertake a governance assessment of the DJB (see paragraph 22 of 
the main text); (ii) prepare a financial model to simulate cash flows under the DBFOT model and 
identify evaluation criteria for the procurement; (iii) suggest a tariff structure based on the 
modeling;  and  (iv)  undertake  a  financial  viability  assessment  of  the  proposed  investment 
program. The Specialist should have demonstrated knowledge of PPP structures. 
 
10.  Economist. The Economist will have a background of having undertaken economic 
analysis for infrastructure projects comprising roads, urban transport, power, telecom and water 
for a minimum 10 years. She/he will (i) undertake economic viability analysis of the proposed

investment program drawing from existing data and willingness to pay studies, and (ii) suggest a 
tariff structure along with the Financial Management Specialist.  
 
11.  Environmental Specialist. The Environmental Specialist will have a background of 
having  undertaken  environmental  assessment  for  infrastructure  projects  comprising  roads, 
urban transport, power, telecom and water for a minimum 5 years. She/he will undertake 
assessing DJB's capacity to respond to ADB's environmental safeguard requirements in the 
Safeguards  Policy  Statement  (2009),  safeguards  assessment  through  initial  environmental 
examinations for project 1, and develop the environmental assessment and review framework 
for the proposed investment program.  
 
12.  Resettlement Specialist. The Resettlement Specialist will have a background of having 
undertaken resettlement planning for infrastructure projects comprising roads, urban transport, 
power, telecom and water for a minimum 5 years. She/he will undertake assessing DJB's 
capacity to respond to ADB's social safeguard requirements in the Safeguards Policy Statement 
(2009), involuntary resettlement assessment and prepare a resettlement plan for project 1 as 
required,  and  develop  the  resettlement  framework  and  indigenous  people’s  development 
framework for the proposed investment program.  
 
13.  Social Development and Gender Specialist. The Social Development and Gender 
Specialist will have a background of having undertaken poverty reduction and social impacts 
assessment, and gender assessment and action planning for a minimum 5 years. The Specialist 
will  work  closely  with  the  social  development  team  in  the  project  management  consultant 
(appointed through advance actions) to prepare the gender action plan for the projects under 
the proposed investment program. 
 
14.  Procurement  Specialist.  The  Procurement  Specialist  will  be  an  Engineer  with 
knowledge of ADB Consulting and Procurement Guidelines with a minimum 5 years experience 
on recruitment of consultants and procurement of civil works and goods on ADB financed 
projects. She/he will (i) assist on advance contracting actions to appoint the PMC; and (ii) assist 
on bidding document preparation and bid process management for the DBFOT contract for the 
WTP. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The DJB will be the TA’s executing agency. It will provide in-kind contributions in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, and communication facilities for 
consultants. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4. 
Consultants will be mobilized in a staggered manner with a focus on prioritizing the advance 
actions on: (i) recruiting the project management consultants, and (ii) undertaking surveys and 
investigations to establish service level benchmarks. 
 
Table A4.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule
